title: Luxembourgish text-to-speech
description: A text-to-speech system for the Luxembourgish language, making digital content accessible to Luxembourgish speakers.
content:
Available at [neiom.io](https://neiom.io)

## The Challenge

Luxembourgish is a unique language spoken by only about 400,000 people worldwide. Despite being one of Luxembourg's three official languages, there was virtually no digital infrastructure for text-to-speech synthesis in Luxembourgish.

## The Solution

I built a complete text-to-speech system that can convert Luxembourgish text into natural-sounding speech. The system uses modern neural text-to-speech techniques to produce high-quality audio output.

## Technical Implementation

The system is built using:
- **Neural TTS models** trained specifically on Luxembourgish speech data
- **Web-based interface** for easy access and testing
- **RESTful API** for integration with other applications
- **Real-time processing** for immediate audio generation

## Key Features

- **Natural pronunciation** of Luxembourgish words and phrases
- **Multiple voice options** for different use cases
- **Fast processing** with real-time audio generation
- **Easy integration** via simple API calls
- **Web interface** for testing and demonstration

## Impact

This project fills a significant gap in digital accessibility for Luxembourgish speakers. It enables:
- Educational content to be made accessible through audio
- Government services to provide audio versions of text
- Media organizations to create audio content in Luxembourgish
- Developers to build voice-enabled applications

## Technical Challenges

The biggest challenge was the limited availability of Luxembourgish speech data. I had to:
- Collect and curate high-quality Luxembourgish audio recordings
- Develop data augmentation techniques to expand the training set
- Fine-tune pre-trained models for the specific phonetic characteristics of Luxembourgish
- Optimize for the unique sound patterns and intonation of the language

## What I Learned

This project taught me that language technology isn't just about the technical implementation—it's about understanding the cultural and linguistic context. Working with a minority language like Luxembourgish required deep research into its phonetic structure and speaking patterns.

I also learned the importance of community involvement in language technology projects. The feedback from native speakers was crucial for improving the quality and naturalness of the generated speech.

## Future Work

I'm considering:
- Expanding to other regional languages
- Adding emotion and intonation control
- Developing mobile applications
- Creating educational tools for language learning

[Visit neiom.io →](https://neiom.io)

title: Building a transformer from scratch
description: A complete implementation of a transformer neural network architecture built entirely from scratch using Rust and Candle. Features RoPE (Rotary Position Embedding) and BBPE (Byte-level BPE tokenization), with full attention mechanisms, positional encoding, and multi-head attention.
content:
There's no rational reason for building a transformer in Rust—except that it's fun. It's like the guy that built a transformer using minecraft redstone, except lamer.

title: Parsed
description: My first big coding project, a mobile app that gives you the five most important news headlines of the day, articles about these headlines written by newspapers from all over the political spectrum. And a bias analysis for each news item presented to you.
content:
Parsed was the first mobile app I ever made. Obviously it wasn't something people wanted, but it taught me a lot and I don't regret one bit of spending two months building this thing. 

2500 downloads.

[Download on the App Store →](https://apps.apple.com/tn/app/parsed/id6743483636)
